content: The Act titled "Bankruptcy Judgeship Act of 2017" extends the temporary office of bankruptcy judges in certain judicial districts. Appointments of additional bankruptcy judges for specific districts are outlined in section 152(a)(1) of title 28, United States Code. Amendments to Title 28 of the United States Code include changes to the United States Trustee System Fund fees for fiscal years 2018 through 2022. The quarterly fee payable will be adjusted based on the balance in the fund, with a minimum fee set at 1 percent of disbursements or $250,000. Additionally, deposits of certain fees collected during this period will be allocated differently according to section 589a(b) of title 28. Amendments to Title 28 of the United States Code will allocate 98% of fees collected to the United States Trustee System Fund and 2% to the general fund of the Treasury. These amendments apply to quarterly fees under section 1930(a)(6) for disbursements starting from the enactment date of the Act. SEC. 5. CLARIFICATION OF RULE ALLOWING DISCHARGE TO GOVERNMENTAL CLAIMS ARISING FROM THE DISPOSITION OF FARM ASSETS UNDER CHAPTER 12 BANKRUPTCIES. Sec. 1232 of title 11, United States Code, addresses unsecured claims of a governmental unit related to the disposition of property used in a farming operation in bankruptcy cases. These claims are treated as pre-petition claims, do not receive priority status, must be included in a repayment plan, and are discharged upon completion of the plan. The text discusses the treatment of claims in bankruptcy cases, specifically regarding the amount to be paid on a claim if the debtor's estate were liquidated in a chapter 7 case. It also addresses the filing of a proof of claim by a governmental unit for a claim that arises after the petition is filed. In bankruptcy cases, if a debtor files a tax return after the petition is filed and the claim relates to the tax return, they must notify the governmental unit responsible for tax collection. The notice should include details of the bankruptcy petition, court location, claim amount, and supporting documentation. The governmental unit must file a proof of claim within 180 days of receiving notice. If they fail to do so, the debtor or trustee can file a claim consistent with the notice. Any claim filed will be determined and allowed or disallowed as per bankruptcy code. Technical and conforming amendments are made to chapter 12 of title 11. The United States Code is amended to provide for the treatment of any claim by a governmental unit as described in section 1232(a) in section 1222. Amendments are also made to section 1228 regarding the filing of proof of claims by governmental units within 180 days. Technical and conforming amendments are made to chapter 12 of title 11. In section 1222, amendments are made to specify the types of debts allowed under the plan and in section 523(a) of this title. Subsection (c)(2) is amended to include exceptions as provided in section 1232(c). Amendments are made to section 1229(a) to provide for the payment of a claim described in section 1232(a) that arose after the date of the filed petition. The amendments made by this section apply to pending bankruptcy cases and those commencing after the date of enactment of the Act. Passed by the Senate on September 5, 2017. The Act aims to amend title 28, United States Code, to allow for the appointment of additional bankruptcy judges.
